aliases.meaning: with it, he goes on all fours
aliases.note: Primary traditional term - use with respect

description.summary: Yee naaldlooshii are harmful witches in Navajo tradition who have gained the power to transform into animals through the violation of sacred taboos. This is NOT folklore or entertainment - it is a serious spiritual and cultural matter for Navajo people.
description.full: Skinwalkers (Yee naaldlooshii) are a specific type of harmful witch in Navajo spiritual tradition. According to Navajo belief, these are individuals who have gained dark supernatural powers through the worst kind of taboo violations, including murder of close family members. They are said to possess the ability to transform into animals - most commonly coyotes, wolves, foxes, eagles, owls, or crows - by wearing the pelts of these creatures. This is not cryptozoology or paranormal entertainment - it is a deeply serious spiritual matter within Navajo culture. Many Navajo people refuse to discuss this subject as speaking of skinwalkers is believed to attract their attention and bring misfortune. Non-Navajo investigation and tourism related to this topic is considered highly disrespectful cultural appropriation.

etymology.origin: Navajo Diné tradition - ancient spiritual belief system predating European contact
etymology.meaning: Yee naaldlooshii literally translates to 'with it, he goes on all fours' referring to animal transformation
etymology.first_use: Ancient - part of traditional Navajo spiritual knowledge

distribution.important_note: Reports from non-Navajo areas (especially 'Skinwalker Ranch' in Utah) often misappropriate and misrepresent Navajo beliefs for commercial purposes.

origins.cultural_roots: Deep roots in Navajo (Diné) spiritual tradition and worldview. Skinwalkers represent the darkest violations of Navajo values and taboos. Their existence is part of a complex spiritual system involving harmony, balance, and consequences for breaking sacred laws.
origins.earliest_accounts: Ancient Navajo oral tradition - predates written records by centuries or millennia
origins.spiritual_context: Part of broader Navajo cosmology including concepts of hózhǫ́ (harmony/beauty) and its violation

history.modern_era: Skinwalker beliefs remain a serious spiritual matter within Navajo communities. Many Navajo people are disturbed by the commercialization and trivialization of their sacred beliefs in popular media and 'paranormal tourism'.

sightings.important_note: We do not collect or promote 'sighting reports' of skinwalkers. This would be deeply disrespectful to Navajo culture and potentially harmful according to Navajo beliefs.

statistics.note: No statistics provided - this is not appropriate for this subject matter

sightings.respect_statement: Navajo people who have had encounters with skinwalkers do not share these stories lightly, if at all. These are not entertainment or data points to be collected.

evidence.cultural_note: This is not a matter of 'evidence' in a Western scientific sense. For Navajo people, skinwalkers are part of their spiritual reality. Demanding 'proof' is disrespectful to their beliefs.
evidence.navajo_perspective: From the Navajo worldview, skinwalkers are real spiritual threats. The validity of this belief should be respected regardless of outside perspectives.
evidence.why_no_evidence_section: Creating an 'evidence' section would treat sacred Navajo spiritual beliefs as cryptozoological curiosities. This is inappropriate and disrespectful.

navajo_spiritual_belief.description: Skinwalkers are human witches who have chosen to violate the most sacred Navajo taboos to gain dark power. They transform using animal pelts and practice harmful magic. This is the authoritative understanding.

navajo_spiritual_belief.status: Traditional belief system of Navajo people

anthropological_perspective.description: Some anthropologists view skinwalker beliefs as serving social functions - reinforcing taboos, explaining misfortune, and maintaining cultural boundaries
anthropological_perspective.note: This perspective, while scholarly, should not override or dismiss genuine Navajo beliefs
